properties.Name: BÃ¦rum, RamsÃ¥sen

properties.Description:
TAKE OFF
Min. certification: PP3/SP3
Max. altitude (TMA): 914 m.a.s.l.
Take off altitude: 315 m.a.s.l. (170 m top-to-bottom).
Orientation: SSE-SV
Note: The shallow slope and steep cliff edge requires good wing control and adequate running speed. Be prepared for a strong vertical drag when you pull up the wing in high winds. Be careful when you lay out the wing on the rocks in the rear part of the take-off. The lines might tangle and break when you pull up the wing.
This is a popular flying site. Pay attention and be aware of the traffic rules.
Airspace boxes: None above take off.
Radio frequency HP/NLF: 154.175 MHz

LANDING
Landing: There are two possible landing fields, see the photo below.
Note: If you use the landing field straight in front, keep as close to the small road as possible in the growing season.
Be aware of the power line that crosses in front of the landing field to the left.
Expect some turbulence in the landing area in high winds.
Parking: Donât block the narrow road (Busoppveien) with parked cars.

properties.Description:
TAKE-OFF
Min. certification: PP2/SP2
Max. altitude (TMA): 914 m.a.s.l.
Take-off altitude: 390 m.a.s.l. (285 m top-to-bottom).
Orientation: WSW-NNE
Note: Expect turbulence in southerly winds.
Parking: Parking along the road is prohibited. Use only designated parking areas.
Road toll: Pay the road toll at each passage.
Unpacking: Unpack your glider in the parking area to avoid obstructing other pilots at take-off.
Aerial sporting box: The Sundvollen box can only be used when activated according to standard operating procedure.
Radio frequency (NLF): 154.175 MHz

LANDING
Landing: During growing season landings are limited to the designated area (see photo). Land as close to the field edge as possible. Always take the shortest way out of the field. Landing on the schoolâs parking lot is prohibited.
Note: Trees around the field creates turbulence in high winds. Be aware of children playing near by.
Parking: The schoolâs parking lot is only for loading and unloading. The road barrier could be closed without notice. Please park at Nedre Kleiva parking, abt. 100 meters past the school road.
Packing: Leave the landing field quickly. Pack your glider in the parking area.

It is a very interesting place to fly with a toll road (25 NOK/car) to the top. There are many places to have an easy take off and landing. This mount is between Aure(MÃ¸re og Romsdal) and KyrksÃ¦terÃ¸ra (SÃ¸r Trondelag). To find it follow the road no. 680. About 10 km from Aure turn left to the optional (longer about 20 km) road no. 680 and drive in the direction to KjÃ¸rsvik. When you cross the 2nd bridge it will be impossible not to see a huge antenna on the top of the Litlfonna. There is a sign showing when you have to take a turn to the toll road to the top. To get to launch you drive up the southern side of MÃ¥ndalen, until you reach a bridge. Take the gravel road to the left of you. That is a 40kr toll road, park at the end of the road then follow the path up to the cabins and the path goes past the top-left cabin and is marked all the way up. Takes about 1h 30m to go up in a medium pace.

Very much space on top, but the n-nw side of it is a cliff start so make shure it's over your head before you leap of. Eastern side is a bit more gradual.

Landings are plentyfull, but ask the owners of the fields if it looks like it will be a problem. (Like the middle of the growth season).
As it often is a wind in from the ocean, the field near the Coop shop is a nice big place to approach, with the possibility of landing on tarmac and thus not anger anyone.

properties.Description:
Depending on the wind direction on top of the mountain you may have to move around and find a better suiting launch site. Coordinates are only approximate - this is a rocky mountain area without any large patches of wing friendly area. Make sure to clear your launch site of rocks and make sure to have good ground handling skills as you probably won't have much space to move around. Forward launch is not recommended.

First and only registered flight here was done as a spontaneous hike-and-fly trip. :-)

The trail to get there is part of a Norwegian mountain excercise package in the municipality of Leirfjord - check out Norwegian website and get the map with parking / trip description for trip number 8 at the provided link.

Drive road E10 from Leknes towards Svolvaer. After passing the Viking museum at Borg continue until over a short bridge and up a slope and park at the highest point of the road. Walk trail to the top, appx 1 hour.

Large area with suitable takeoffs for all winds. Main wind for soaring southwest. Various landings, by the parking of the car altitude difference 250 m, else 340 m. Watch out for aerial cables.

Be aware at windy days from SW, there will be 2 wind direction meeting. One from SW above the sea, and anotherother from SSE (along the valley and small lake) Meeting point of these might make some turbulence.

properties.Description:
TAKE-OFF
Minimum certification: PP2/SP2
Max altitude (TMA): 1067 m.a.s.l.
Take off altitude: 460 m.a.s.l. (290 m top-to-bottom).
Orientation: SSW-W
Note: North-westerly winds may cause turbulence. To avoid unreasonable burden to local residents PP2 pilots should have an assistant at take-off in case of tree landings.
Parking: Don't block the road with parked cars.
Road toll: Pay the road toll at each passage. See landownerâs instructions at the farmyard.
Unpacking: Please unpack your glider along the small road to avoid obstructing other pilots at take-off.
Airspace boxes: None above take off (see map).
Radio frequency HP/NLF: 154.175 MHz

LANDING
Landing: During the growing season landings are limited to the designated area (see photo below).
Note: Trees along the road creates turbulence in high winds. Keep distance. South-easterly winds may cause turbulence over the landing field. Tree landings are often observed by the local residents. If no assistance is required please cancel emergency services immediately.
Parking: Park the cars according to the landowner signs.
Driving: Please drive very slowly across the farmyard.
The road is closed in the winter season.
Packing: Leave the landing field quickly. Pack your glider in front of the barn.

For more information about this flying site please contact Trude Ãverlie, phone 97128678.

Fint termikksted ved sÃ¸rvestlige til vestlige vinder og panoramautsikt over Oslo. Flystedet er krevende bÃ¥de i forhold til takeoff og landing, og det flys over tett bebyggelse med mye ledningsstrekk og ingen gode alternative landinger. Flystedet krever svÃ¦rt god skjermkontroll og minimum PP3.

Landing er pÃ¥ gressletta ved fotballbanene mot nordvest. OmrÃ¥det kan vÃ¦re turbulent pÃ¥ termiske dager, og det er flere hÃ¸ye lysmaster pÃ¥ sletta.

OBS OBS: FotballmiljÃ¸et er negative til at vi lander pÃ¥ sletta nÃ¥r det er treningsaktivitet, og lokale fotballklubber Ã¸nsker Ã¥ fÃ¥ oss stengt ute fra omrÃ¥det dersom vi forstyrrer aktiviteten for mye. Banemester har i samtale 28.04.14 bedt oss om Ã¥ lande pÃ¥ "haugen", se kart, og Ã¥ ikke gjÃ¸re innflygning over banene nÃ¥r det er mye aktivitet. Tidspunktene dette gjelder er sÃ¦rlig tirsdag-torsdag kl. 17-20. Fredag-mandag vil det vÃ¦re mindre aktivitet, og vi kan ogsÃ¥ bruke andre omrÃ¥der til Ã¥ lande sÃ¥ lenge disse ikke er i bruk. Derfor er det SVÃRT VIKTIG at den som skal fly nÃ¥r det er aktivitet pÃ¥ landing har svÃ¦rt god kontroll pÃ¥ innflyvning og landing og LANDER SLIK VIST PÃ KARTET.

-----------------------------------------------

Nice site for thermals on south west to westerly winds and panoramic views of Oslo. The site is demanding both in terms of takeoff and landing, and there are no good alternative landings. Flying at this site therefor requires very good wing control and minimum PP3 licence/experienced intermediate.

The take-off requires very good launch technique due to the narrow and short space and the wind conditions caused by the cliff formation.

Landing is located on the north side of the soccer fields to the northwest. The area can be turbulent in thermal days.

ATTENTION: The local football clubs are negative to our use of the field during their training activities and they want to get us banned from the site if we interfere too much with their activity. The field master has asked us to land on the area showed on the map and to do the approach outside of the field when the field is in use for soccer activities. This applies particularly on Tuesday-Thursday at 17-20. Friday-Monday there will be less activity, and we can also use other areas of the field for landing as long as they are not in use. Therefore, it is VERY IMPORTANT that the pilot flying when there is activity on the soccer field has very good control on the approach and landing, and ONLY LAND ON THE AREA INDICATED ON THE MAP AND DO APPROACH OUTSIDE OF THE FIELD.

properties.Description:
Byrkjedal (candle 'factory'/eatery), here you have the road from Ãlgard, the road going up to Hunnedal/Sirdal,one to Gloppedalsura/VikesÃ¥, and then the steep road directly in front going to Maudal - take this road up the swings, after the last swing you come to a parking area on the left (East side of the road), park here.

Best start is a few minutes walk to the obvious hill side above the last swing in the road (same side as parking). With wind it's also possible to start on the little nob on the other side of the road (West side) this is closer to the parking and picture shows Per flying with just enough wind to glide out, Mel flying second in dying breeze, touched down twice and had to run before coming over the lip, I had to forward start and was airborne, then running, then face planted, then crossed the road and had no problems taking off.

Care must be taken for the power lines both in the take off area, hillside, and valley/landings, easy to avoid but check where they are.

This valley is a small steep valley that runs North to South, in light airs there should be no issues flying here, in stronger conditions appraise the valley winds as these may cause turbulence/much stronger winds when existing into the main valley.

Plenty of places to land - no agreed landing - check landing before flying.

properties.Description:
This is the hill on the left opposite the crane school (new industrial area) when driving up the hill (South) on the E39 away from ÃlgÃ¥rd.

Apparently this is an old flysted that has fallen out of use.

To fly here you must ask the farmer. We (Jostein & I) landed in a field with sheep this is owned by a different farmer to the one that owns the land where the take off is and the access tractor track (his fields are better to land in but are crop fields and there's nowhere to park your car at the second farm in).

If you take the second bridge over the river you can park next to a transformer station (it's the field in front of this that we landed in and it's owned by the farm directly above the field.

There is a tractor track that is suitable for a Subaru or better to drive up to ~ 320 m in between the two summits. This is owned by the second farm along (shabby run down white looking house, or take the first bridge over rive from {ÃlgÃ¥rd}, turn right and itâs the farm in front of you): BUT YOU MUST ASK THE FARMER IF YOU WANT TO USE THIS ROAD. WE HAVE NO AGREEMENT FOR THE ROAD OR THE LANDING.

Takes 30 mins (ish) to walk to summit from the top of the tractor trail. Go to the ridge to the North East of the tractor trail and you will find a path (marked with blue posts). Make sure you sign the summit book with the appropriate comment on paragliding.

There are marked trails going up one on the front and one on the back but I have yet to take either.

There are plenty of start options (and landing options). However this is a PP3+++ start (scared the crap out of me starting in light winds, with five metres to run after laying out the glider, stuff the take off and you have 200 m to figure out what you did wrong before St Peter hands you your wings...).

Main flying direction N-W.

Should be hangable in the right conditions.

(Jostein, feel free to edit/Norwegiansise this description).

Bit baffled as to why someone changed the name to only 'Gjesdal'... not too helpful...

Altitude limit 457 m if you fly towards ÃlgÃ¥rd, 762 m if you fly South... this hill is right on the change.

Den gamle HG starten,rett over veien ned mot Frafjord.Veien er nÃ¥ stengt med bom.Kun en 2-3 minutter Ã¥ gÃ¥ fra parkeringsplassen til starten.Ikke god plass Ã¥ rigge.SkrÃ¥tt med smÃ¥trÃ¦r og busker.Stupstart,med ikke altfor mye Ã¥ springe pÃ¥.Kanskje ikke den beste plassen for PG akkurat her.Da mÃ¥ en nok finne andre plasser i nÃ¦rheten.
Det finnes en start til lenger oppe,ogsÃ¥ stupstart,men tar en 15 minutter ekstra Ã¥ gÃ¥.Flatere,med mindre vegetasjon.

Didn't know about this one and made following entry for Gilja... which is the same place/start:

According to Jan (HG-pilot) & one of the locals at Frafjord, this is an old HG start that no one uses any more.

Three warnings:

1. the valley is only ~ 2 km wide, you can take off from West to East (in the right conditions) but it will be prone to turbulence from especially North... therefore I'd only consider flying here in NW winds of hangable strength;

2. the starts are stup starts in tight areas... i.e. no forward start potential/zero wind starts (PG). All the places that we had a look at, you had little space to lay a glider out in amongst the rocks and youâd be quite close to the edge i.e. if you canât do a backwards start contained in a small area, donât try to fly a PG from here. There are many rocks here (but the tops are clear of trees, hillside is heavily wooded), so you are liable to snagging rocks and damaging lines/glider. There has to be enough wind to do a backwards start;

3. we have no agreement with any of the farmers as to landing areas. With the exception of the campsite, all the other fields are cultivated. Depending on the wind direction, the campsite might not be such a good place to land. Suggest burning off height on take off side of the gulley.

Suspect this is a good launch area for HG... once you get the glider to the start(s).

To get to the landing, drive through the (new) tunnel (that the kommune canât afford the electricity for the interior lights!). We looked at various spots for landing but all the fields were cultivated or had livestock in. So we ended up in the NW corner by the sea, which is where the campsite is. Here the grass is cut. We could not find anyone to ask if we could land here, not for lack of trying. There is parking here (and boats if anyone has an unplanned glider assisted dip).

Drive back through the tunnel, and take the first left (sharp left on exit of tunnel and it doubles back on itself). This is heading towards GiljastÃ¸len. Take the (old) road up and drive past the âski centreâ (RHS), Hjelpekorps (LHS), GiljastÃ¸lvatn (RHS) to the top of the road. Park in parking on RHS by volcanic plug (if you carry on driving you get to the barrier blocking progress down the old road), turn around in good turning place here and drive back ~ 100 m, and park in the (same) car park, now on your left hand side.

There is no path that follows the fjord side. Opposite the car park there is one cabin set into the trees, with a path to the left of it. Follow this one up, work your way along from the huts (there are paths to the huts). The initial steep climb through the cabins brings you to undulating terrain; then head out to the edge, as there is no path you might find yourself going up and down more than required. We tried several tops, most of them have the same general layout, small area on top, steep drop off, road and trees some metres below. Didnât find a good start, clear of rocks with plenty of room to layout and run.

Walk takes about 15 mins, but you will probably take longer as you get lulled into ânext-summit-itusâ, which is a condition where you believe that the next summit/top will be better than the one you are on (it wonât be, but good luck...).

Tremendous hang potential if wind is in the right direction. Do not go too far/too low west as there is nowhere to land, and no easy access along shore... go here and if you lose lift you will be swimming!


The place marked on the photo as looking like a good start is. Park in last parking place on right/East side of road (when driving up). Walk up car track going east for ~200 m until you come to a small lake on your left. There is one cabin at the other end of this lake and (presumably) the folk who own that cabin have made an excellent path to it, think nice thoughts towards these folk as you follow this path on the west side of the lake, at the end of the lake carry on walking in the same direction as parallel to the lake and this brings you out on the place marked on the picture. Stup start, we cleared some trees away, this is a good place to launch from, and takes about 10 easy minutes to walk to (without snow).
Altitude limit 1067 m

properties.Description:
This is the area at the end of the road when you drive along the south side of Ãrsdalsvatn.

Drive along the E39 from Stavanger to Bjerkreim (~ 50 minutes to drive). Turn off at Bjerkreim, cross Bjerkreim elve (the river) and then follow the signs to Lauperak. The driver there is through some lovely terrain.

When you get almost to the end of the road, you come out into a farm area on your left (below the road) and a hut area on your right (above the road). There is also a military road on the right (south side); the military road climbs up to ~ 906 m, giving take offs both to the north and south, but you need a key and permission to drive it.

There are a number of take offs in this area but NOTE WE DO NOT HAVE PERMISSION TO LAND ON THE FARM LAND BELOW â WHICH ARE THE ONLY SAFE LANDING AREAS. AT THE MOMENT LANDING IS BY PERSMISSION ONLY.

When we flew it was in March, so the animals were not out and the fields were without crops. We spoke to the last farmer (quite literarily, âthe man at the end of the roadâ), who was happy to have us land on his property when there were no animals out and no crops in the fields, he didnât sound too keen for later on in the season when Per tried sounding him out. We also got the distinct impression that the three farms were not a close knit community.

Plenty of take offs. Be aware that there are power cables, also be aware that there are very few places to land along Ãrsdalsvatn, and no road access to large parts of this area.

Lots of potential at this area. Lots of potential take offs as well.

Munkholmen - prison island, fort and former monastery

The fascinating Monks' Island is not to be missed. This little island with a fort is situated in Trondheim harbour and served as Trondheim's execution ground and special prison in ancient times.

Today the island is a popular recreational area, with good bathing and a popular restaurant.

And from 9. may 2010, also a place to tow paragliders in the air for a spectacular flight in the midst of Trondheimsfjorden. Only for experienced pilots as the landing is a bit small.

For acroshows and demostration flights mainly . )
